A First Reaction To: McKean and Morrison’s (2004)[1] Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth (15th Anniversary Edition)

This is the best-selling graphic novel to date, in massive part thanks to the publicity generated by the Burton Batman (i.e., the visibility of the franchise at the time), partly due to the presented ensemble of villains, i.e., that one gets to see practically all of the important Batman villains (i.e., the marketability of the product as perceived by DC), partly because it is an inspired idea to go inside the place where Batman has been putting people away for years and years in the comics (i.e., Morrison’s notion), an very, very mostly due to McKean’s almost always inspired illustrations.

I don’t know enough to say with any real sense of certainty, but McKean is certainly one of the best, if not essentially the first (this is where my uncertainty is), to take the word “graphic” in “graphic novel” in its most genuine sense(and not merely an illustrated novel). It’s not that he was the first to “illustrate” a novel in a spooky or inspired way, was not the first to go beyond the concept of “drawing” comics—that had been done ages before. If Watchmen posited a shift of paradigm, some kind of sea-change in what graphic novels could be or do, then McKean is again right at the vanguard of offering the same kind of paradigm shift or sea-change in illustration—and I’m saying that that’s what is “really” mean (ultimately) by a graphic novel. Without McKean’s work, this could only have been a passable one-off I suspect—I’ll defend this later. But it’s why I list his name first above, rather than Morrison’s.

Nichols (1980)[2] describes this difference (in a context of Tarot decks that come with accompanying booklets of explanation compared to those that do not):

Although the text which accompanies the Tarot … is usually introduced as an elucidation of the symbols portrayed on the cards, the net effect is more that of an illustrated book. In other words, it is as if the Tarot cards were devised as illustrations for certain verb al concepts rather than that the cards erupted spontaneously first and the text was inspired by them. As a result, the personalities and objects pictured in these cards seem more allegorical in character than symbolic; the pictures appear to illustrate verbalized concepts rather than suggesting feelings and insights wholly beyond the reach of words (5-6).

This difference between illustrated book as allegory versus (graphic) image as symbol points to what I mean by McKean’s sense of imagery. Nichols (1908) further points out:

Jung often stressed the difference between a symbol and a sign. A sign, he said, denotes a specific object or idea which can be translated into words (e.g., a striped pole means barber shop; an X means railroad crossing). A symbol stands for something which can be presented in no other way and whose meaning transcends all specifics and includes many seeming opposites (7).

This distinction will come into play later with Morrison’s text. And while I am entirely disposed to describe McKean’s art as graphic, symbolic, or groundbreaking,[3] I’m inclined to give far less credit to Morrison than may be typical.[4]

An analogy. I had the unhappy experience of watching Jackson’s (2012) The Hobbit: An Unexpected Bore, and besides most of the very obviously awful stuff in it—random stone giant battles, and riddle-guessing episode longer and less engaging the Warhol’s (1963) Sleep—by far the most irking thing for me was the ultra-fanboy gush involved as the film went to ridiculous lengths to get every important figure from the Lord of the Rings trilogy into the film. Obviously, for fans it might be breathtaking for Galadriel to reappear, &c., but the entire way the scene is filmed, the whole attitude evinced by the film throughout, arises obviously and painfully from fanboy gush rather than genuine narrative opulence. One can practically hear the developers talking amongst themselves saying, “Oh, wouldn’t it be awesome is Saruman showed up …”[5]

Thankfully, the parade of villains in Arkham Asylum isn’t necessarily overshadowed by this kind of fanboy gush, but most of all this is due to McKean’s work, because certainly Morrison adds nothing to the mystique of most of the villains—except, of course, the Joker, but more on that soon enough. At the end of the book, McKean provides one-page or multiple panel symbolic mugshots of several principals in the book, including villains, most with text with the script of the text adjusted according to the psychosis of each character—and so one almost doesn’t notice that Croc’s is an empty square with a few strips of scaled flesh on the right, and a white claw-scrawl, the scrawl being his “words”. Black Mask’s picture is an empty box, and his name isn’t even underlined like all the rest. These, of course, are goodies at the back of the book; McKean has already populated the pages with his pictures-say-a-thousand-words moments that do all the work of revisioning this pantheon of “evil” well-nigh infinitely more than Morrison’s text. In fact, it generally seems that Morrison almost has no interest in such “background” figures, and when they are forefronted, their out-of-context (or out-of-the-blue appearance) ends up betting trumped by McKean’s considerably more interesting strangeness and vision.

This is most true of the Joker, of course, but at least here one can say that Morrison does do some work—nonetheless, the greater part of the Joker’s super-sanity, as Morrison calls it, gets conveyed most of all though McKean’s images. At this point, almost 30 years on from the original, with an entire subfranchise built up around Arkham-related stuff, it’s hard to tell how much of not Mark Hamill’s voice I hear when I read the Joker’s obnoxiously illegible script[6] or to what extent Hamill simply correctly pronounced the meta-text of the Joker (defined, in very large part, by this book). In terms of being groundbreaking (see note 3 below), this text pulls together in a defining way a long-stranding strand in the franchise—what is Batman’s sanity vis-à-vis those he puts away. If this had always been kind of covert and coy (and thus numinous, in the same way that Batman’s sexuality seemed at times to get different varieties of ambiguous), then this text resets the gravity of the Batman world, and makes everything ultimately about Batman and the Joker as seemingly in some way mirror images of one another—though whether the mirror is true or a funhouse mirror has remained the new and essential numinous mystery in it all.

However, one needs only glance through the book, even cursorily, to understand unambiguously that it is the Joker who is hyper-defined and brought into focus as a symbol—Batman, visually, hardly appears in it at all, and I’m not sure Morrison even noticed. As for hyper-defining a symbol, way back when, in 1897 Bram Stoker took the noisome monster of the vampire and dressed him up in the seductive image of an old Wallachian count. The seduction hinges precisely in our failure to recognize Dracula still as a monster. Of course, Stoker was busy with sexual tension and Victorian insanity as the historically local manifestations of monstrosity, which adds specifics to the character of the monster, but he nevertheless rediscovered the symbol that the vampire had always represented. Anne Rice did it again, in this case using the emotional pathos of the vampiric condition to seduce us into forgetting the vampire is a monster—as Louis makes so brilliantly and perfectly clear at the end of Interview with a Vampire (1976)—indubitably Rice’s best vampire book. There, Rice encoded stoker’s sexual element in a lurid miasma of homosexual suggestion; this was pre-HIV. In both cases, as also the image of the vampire itself (pre-Stoker or Rice), this was simply an adequate symbolism of the “evil” or “fear” that the “monster” always represents. By symbol, I mean in Jung’s sense: “something which can be presented in no other way and whose meaning transcends all specifics and includes many seeming opposites” (Nichols, 1980,7). By rediscovered, then, this means that one does not “construct” symbols; we encounter something like them (in dreams, nightmares, visions, &c), and then try to adequately embodiment them in image, text, sound. Such is what happens here with the Joker in McKean’s imagery—in the character’s thoroughly morphing look, McKean has provided the (visual) symbol of the Joker as unlimited chaos.[7]

Morrison does manage to throw at least a couple of good punches in here. Arkham (the asylum’s founder) has a little speech about the freedom he has obtained since he’s gone insane; “I see now the virtue in madness for this country knows no law nor any boundary. I pity the poor shades confined to the Euclidean prison that is sanity” (57). Another of Morrison’s better moments in the text, after Batman liberates the inmates and tells them, “You’re free. You’re all free,” the Joker replies, “Oh, we know that already.” The very phrasing here is inspired, even if it is followed by the workaday, though necessary, “But what about you?” The phrasing of “Oh, we know that already” is not smug—smugness would be unnecessary—but conveys a touch of surprise on Joker’s part that Batman has stated something already so perfectly clear to the inmates; the Joker seems (to me) surprised a bit that Batman is reporting this tidbit like it should come as news to anyone inside.

The other best moment for Morrison comes when two inmates propose taking off Batman’s mask to see his real face, and Joker replies, “Oh, don’t be so predictable, for Christ’s sake! That is his real face.”[8] The idea that we might put on a mask to show our true face seems a fruitful provocation, particularly in a context where Joker’s face in the book does anything except stay stable—the Joker has no filter, no mask (that’s why he’s insane), so what does it mean that Batman’s true face is his mask? Furthermore, since a mask is a limitation—i.e., limits the expression one’s face makes—this stands in marked contrast to the unlimited freedom that madness promises, as Dr. Arkham insists. Is Batman’s mask his Euclidean prison then?[9]

More intriguing to me is the idea that we only become ourselves by donning a mask. Jung[10] describes the persona—essentially this is a person’s social face, and in this respect is exactly a mask as discussed above, or potentially:[11] hence we have people who are a saint outside the house and a tyrant in the home, or are domineering commander in public who wants to be humiliated by a dominatrix in private, &.But more broadly, Jung also speaks of the personality per se, which rests on the limitless chaos (in a positive and negative sense) of the unconscious. The ego is the conscious part of personality in this sense, and that ego might don whatever face it does for social purposes; but the ego itself, whatever its “interior” horrors or not, is the filter through which all that we think about our personality (directly and indirectly conscious) enters.[12]

There are two main things then that I conclude from this project.

First: Batman’s insanity is that he doesn’t kill people. Since it seems that he kills Croc (in self-defense or not), once you kill one, why not kill them all? I’m not interested in canon on this point; I’m talking about the internal (diegetic) consistency of this story—why didn’t he kill them all the moment he walked in, &c. One might have an “oh shit” moment about this; “he finally did it, he snapped,” but then why does it stop there?[13] We could say it’s in some kind of realization along these lines that make him free everyone—his guilt, realizing that he is a killer, and so should kill them all: so the only recourse is to release them all. The more consistent conclusion would be to imprison himself—the resort of leaving it up to a coin-toss from Dent is cheap, especially since the outcome is determined by Fate (i.e., the author)—but perhaps as a criminal after all, Batman is not about to imprison himself—but that’s a franchise buster. Batman would have to move to Sin City at that point. &c.

There are further muddles this can get into, and I’m not interested in allowing the conclusion “Batman’s insanity is that he doesn’t kill people” to stand. The inside/outside distinction of Arkham, that questions what sanity is or is not, doesn’t get to become the litmus test for the morality of murdering other human beings (as a commentary on how our real world should or could be arranged). If insanity is a social problem (and it is), then the unenviable position Batman is in is a function of the society he lives in. In that world, it is radically heroic not to kill the likes of Arkham’s inhabitants, especially as they regularly get free, and it is the fault of Gotham that its inhabitants can’t work out how to arrange the social order so that Arkham’s inhabitants ever have to act like they do, or even come to be people who must inhabit the place.[14]

Madness, as a literary theme, has a pitfall. As Dr. Arkham notes, its country has no boundaries—with madness, all bets are off. Everything is on the table; anything might happen. And the central problem of that is that anything might happen, and so what does happen loses some of its significance for that reason. Hamlet starts aping at madness, and after that everything gets a bit more fuzzy. In Peter Brooks’ (1967) unbelievably good Marat/Sade, he does a number of things (thanks to the play’s original) to let things get riotous without becoming meaningless, and so I’m not surprised to see in Morrison’s notes references to Marat/Sade, because it is surely one of the best places to go for “advice” on how to literarily write an asylum.

So, second: the consequence of this is that is reduces the duration of Joker’s actions to a single frame at a time—no action by the Joker in the text has a before and after, so to speak.

This requires some evidence, and I want to start with an illustration from The Dark Knight (2008). If there is one moment in that movie when I am entirely certain that the Joker is lying, it is when he says to Harvey Dent, “Do I look like a guy with a plan?” At least one blogger answered this question for himself with a definitive, “Nope, he doesn’t look like that at all.”[15] I was of the impression Joker actually had all kinds of plans, simply in the sense of being organized—you don’t load up two ferries with explosives by accident.[16] But partly this is a curse of the film medium.

By contrast, in Arkham Asylum, the Joker can literally be anything in any frame—McKean can draw him with or without any connection to the preceding frame or the one to come. This allows the Joker to be depicted as embodied chaos far more visually than in a movie, where hundreds of individual frames are flickering by. Nonetheless, I think Nolan still tried to capture that by variations in make-up, and very memorably in that shot where the Joker is leaving the hospital in a nurse’s outfit and walking strangely before it blows up. In Arkham Asylum, the moment by moment embodiment of chaos—which when it is stretched out in a movie scene starts to look like whimsy, whether for good or ill, more than embodied chaos—comes across as vividly as could be.

This is distinct from on the one hand from that “randomness” ordinarily associated with chaos[17] but also from “instinct” which is the “cruel” form of whimsy in psychopathic (insane) individuals. If we try to “explain” the root of the Joker’s actions, we call him mad, impulsive, chaotic, dangerously whimsical, that sort of thing. In part thanks to Arkham Asylum, the shorthand designation for this (as I’ve already called it) is now officially “embodied chaos”.[18] To be exactly precise, as soon as chaos is embodied, it is no longer chaos—it has taken on a direction, a telos, it moves toward an end, even if it changes its mind a moment later.

However, Chaos—one may go back to the source of everything in Hesiod’s Theogony—is the “gap” (“Borrowed from Ancient Greek χάος : khaos, ‘vast chasm, void’”) out of which everything issues, or has issued. In other words, chaos is not the chaos that ensues.

Appendix

The genuine end of this blog entry is the above. What follows is my specific critique and correction of one example of Morrison’s too frequently inept writing (beyond the other critiques I raised above), and I’m including this because I feel obligated to do so because it is one thing say, “That could be better” and another to demonstrate how.

The most garish kind of lapse from Morrison involves over-selling an idea; this is most awful in the totally pedestrian psychology underpinning Batman’s consciousness—it’s boringly, even merely conventional: Mommy angst, dead parents; Morrison’s comments make this even worse, when the “pussy” Batman is said to overcome his “Mother attachment” (that’s Morrison’s capital m) by spearing (the male) Croc. Blah. And there is a lot of this. For instance, I randomly open the book, and here is some text, from Arkham’s journal; I use ¶ to indicate separate captions; the bold is in the original.

And I return to my ritual perambulations. ¶ My movements through the house have become as formalized as ballet and I feel that I have become an essential part of some incomprehensible biological process. ¶ The house is an organism, hungry for madness. ¶ It is the maze that dreams. ¶ And I am lost.

The first most obvious thing to go must assuredly be that last caption, “And I am lost” (bold emphasis on that last word making it that much more crystal clear that it is over-sold hysteria; and that’s not a detail from the book’s letterer; the script shows Morrison had it in the original).

However, let’s go sequentially. In which case, the first adjustment would be to remove the clunky bubble three (“the house is an organism, hungry for madness”). The phrase “the house is an organism” is fine; it is the “hungry for madness” part that is silly and overblown; more why this is below. However, even “the house is an organism” is not necessary, because it has already been said that “I have become an essential part of some incomprehensible biological process” in the previous caption—so “the house is an organism” is redundant and serves only to cover up McKean’s winding “maze” illustration in the background, which he has embodied, strikingly n gradually, as a snake skeleton. So, then, the text “should” read:

And I return to my ritual perambulations. ¶ My movements through the house have become as formalized as ballet and I feel that I have become an essential part of some incomprehensible biological process. ¶ It is the maze that dreams.

Let’s be clear about something. The point of this demonstration is to indicate how Morrison over-sells his text at times.[19] I got to it by randomly opening the book; I might be able to do the same on any page.[20] Moreover, whether you “like” the text I deleted or whether you “think it works” is moot. We don’t have the benefit of having encountered the passage without what I’m calling the errors in it first. And so, in defending Morrison’s choices in such cases, we would be concocting excuses for mistakes after the fact, which is the reader’s prerogative, but it is beside the point. What’s needed would be evidence for the contributing function of the phrase(s) in question at each point in the story. One might prevail with the deleted bubble 3, because its main fault is that it is redundant (“the house is an organism”) though the cheese (“hungry for madness”) should still go.

Supposedly the doctor is despairing here, and “hungry for madness” has a ring of enthusiasm—an abyssal pit might be more consonant with his descriptive mood, Nietzsche’s gazing abyss even, rather than something that is “hungry” much less for an abstract noun like “madness”. “Hungry for misery” or “hungry for suffering” would seem more appropriate if you must have an abstract not—but I propose this only if one simply cannot do away with the line. But when you get to the phrase “And I am lost” (emphasis on lost), the argument is certainly lost. The gesture is merely manipulative—it too clearly dictates to me (rather than evokes in me, or a reader) the sense of the doctor’s plight. It basically displays a lack of faith in McKean’s imagery, which has already established (on the page) the mood that Morrison is trying to reach for.
